sentences: Joseph Antonio Cartagena (born August 19, 1970), better known by his stage name Fat Joe, is an American rapper from New York City.
section: N/A

sentences: He began his music career as a member of hip hop group Diggin' in the Crates Crew (D.I.T.C.), then forged a solo career and set up his own label, Terror Squad, to which he signed Big Pun, Remy Ma, Tony Sunshine, Cuban Link, Armageddon, Prospect, Triple Seis, and a then-unknown DJ Khaled, as well as discover producers Cool & Dre.
section: N/A

sentences: Fat Joe's debut solo album, Represent, was released in 1993 and spawned the single "Flow Joe", which reached number one on the Billboard Hot Rap Songs chart.
section: N/A

sentences: His most commercially successful album to date was Jealous Ones Still Envy (J.O.S.E.) (2001); it was certified platinum by the RIAA and internationally certified silver by the BPI, as well as reaching the top 100 on multiple music charts.

sentences: Fat Joe was born Joseph Antonio Cartagena in the Bronx borough of New York City, where he was raised by parents of Puerto Rican and Cuban descent.

== Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: Legal issues ===
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: On September 8, 1998, Fat Joe and Big Pun were arrested on assault charges for hitting a man with a baseball bat and stealing the man's gold chain on June 14 that year.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: Joe was arrested again on May 12, 2002, for allegedly fighting with another man at B.B. King's Blues Club in Times Square, but the charges were dropped on January 10, 2003.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: In two murder cases, Fat Joe has been named a witness:
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: Joe's former bodyguard, Jose Mulero (also known as Sing Sing), was arrested on September 17, 2004, for the April 15, 1994, shooting death of 16-year-old Ernesto Rivera at a Bronx nightclub.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: Responding to a subpoena, Fat Joe claimed to have heard the shooting and seen people fleeing the scene, but investigators argued that he was standing closer to Mulero, by a door.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: Miami Beach police also named Fat Joe as a witness in a Memorial Day double homicide outside David's Cafe II in South Beach.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: Jermaine Wufgang Chamberline of Miami Gardens was accused of shooting Lessli Paz and Joey Navarro to death on that morning; Fat Joe and the two victims were sitting in a rented Cadillac Escalade parked outside the restaurant when a fight broke out between passengers and another man.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: In December 2012, Fat Joe pleaded guilty to tax evasion for not paying income tax on over $3 million from 2007 to 2010.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: On June 24, 2013, he was sentenced to four months in prison for tax evasion.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===

sentences: He began the sentence on August 26, 2013, and was released on November 28, 2013.
section: == Personal life == | === Legal issues ===
== Personal life == | === LGBT beliefs and support ===

sentences: LGBT beliefs and support =
section: == Personal life == | === LGBT beliefs and support ===
== Personal life == | === LGBT beliefs and support ===

sentences: During an interview with Vlad TV, Joe stated that while he is not gay himself, he believes that gay people should not hide their sexuality and should stand by who they are.
section: == Personal life == | === LGBT beliefs and support ===

sentences: He mentioned that it's possible that he has done songs with gay rappers and that there are likely several gay people besides rappers in the hip hop industry who are in the closet, describing it as a "Gay Mafia".
section: == Personal life == | === LGBT beliefs and support ===

sentences: His comments came after he was asked to comment on radio personality Mister Cee being arrested for public lewdness with a transgender sex worker.
section: == Personal life == | === LGBT beliefs and support ===
